comments: It was a virtual seminar.
N/A

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We learned a lot about different political philosophers' ideas on morality and violence. I especially appreciated reading Gandhi, which I hadn't done before this course.
Deeply philosophical understanding around the subject of violence and resistance.
How to think critically about morality in politics
Critical thinking abilities; knowledge on foundational political thought

I learned about different theories of political violence and considerate how leftists including Che Guevara and Franz Fanon conceive of the challenge of decolonization. I also has the chance to write and learn about Thoreau and Gandhi's conceptions of truth and how they respond to the lack of "truth" in politics.
We learned critical thought concerning the intersection of ethics and politics by essentially attempting to answer the question, what does morality in politics look like?
I learned how to analyze morality and violence in politics both theoretically and through real case studies

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The readings were incredibly interesting, and Professor Kapustin was wonderful in teaching them and helping us to understand them much better. Sometimes I would go into the class not fully understanding what I'd just read, but I would leave with a much clearer understanding.

Strengths: Easily one of the most eloquent and passionate speakers at Yale. The full embodiment of the Yale experience. 
Weaknesses: None.

Strengths: Professor Kapustin 
Weaknesses: not much, although some of the readings were boring (but most of them weren't)

Professor Kapustin is perhaps one of the best professors I have had at Yale. He is PASSIONATE, he is charitable, and kind. He will devote a full single spaced page to offer feedback to your essays and is an incredible joy to meet with for office hours. This is my second class with him and I full-heartedly suggest enrolling in his classes at least once. 

The strengths are the readings and the seminar structure, guided by Kapustin. The only weakness is that the syllabus is too ambitious-- we spend to little time on each author. I just wish one could either break down the readings to focus on about half as many authors or have more seminar discussions. Really an excellent class I just wish we had more time to spend delving deep. \
strengths: Professor Kapustin's remarks and insights and how he linked our different readings, the readings, people's participation

I truly believe the only weakness to this course was the circumstance which required it to be taught online. It is more difficult to create complex discussions over zoom, but professor Kapustin did a fantastic job at making sure students were engaging in conversation with each other as well as himself.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It worked well over zoom.
The seminar format in virtual form succeeded, I was very engaged

Unfortunately, the online education format detracts from our education noticeably. Yale should obviously lower tuition and frankly it's an outrage that they haven't. The notion that online education is anything similar (especially for humanities classes/seminars) is absurd on its face. Despite the incredible teaching and the fact that I was deeply invested in my class material, this format and the fact that the libraries operate on sporadic and limited hours makes genuine engagement in our classes tenuous at best. Since there is no actual solution to many of these problems with online education, I really think we should be lowering tuition. It's not the teachers' fault most of the time. It is just that motivation to genuinely learn is halted by the challenges of our external reality.
I think seminars naturally allow for a greater degree of virtual engagement than most lectures
I was remarkably surprised at how engaging and inclusive the virtual seminar was it was almost indistinguishable from my past in-person seminar with professor Kapustin.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! This was a very interesting course, and I was particularly appreciative of it being a more upper-level political philosophy course because on top of learning a lot from Professor Kapustin, I also learned a lot from the other students.
Yes. This professor is among the best at Yale. The readings and class discussions are engaging and interactive.

Yes! Professor Kapustin loves the material that he teaches, and you can tell. Definitely take this course if you have the chance. Hes an incredible professor and will push you to understand philosophy in new ways.
Yes, if they want to improve their knowledge of political philosophers in a seminar setting
Absolutely. You would really miss out as an EPE or Polisci student if you did not study with Kapustin.
Absolutely! Must take course for students of political philosophy,  ethics, religion, history and other humanities fields.

Yes! I was a little vary of some of the case study readings and initially thought the topic may be too specific for my liking, but I really really enjoyed the course. Prof Kapustin is one of the kindest and most knowledgeable professors!

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student! Prof Kapustin teaches students how to think, analyze, and interpret text on their own as opposed to simply preaching his own interpretations as many professors do. The material is extremely interesting and supplies a diverse account of how philosophy and definitions of morality have historically influenced politics. I would recommend this class to anyone especially interested in ethics or political science! (not a gut)
